step1.question: Can you evidence you meet all applicable Disclosure Regulations?
step1.comments: The new new Disc Regs will provide new requirements and options to be provided when relevant to the customer. This will require changes to websites, paper versions etc. and more than one disclosure through the process.

step1.question: Can you evidence that you clearly explain the extent (scope) of services and products you can provide and areas of competency including any limitations to your authorities, potential or know conflicts of interest so a client can make an informed choice whether to use your services?
step1.source:
FSLAA S431 J
Code Std 2
Code Std 4
Disclosure Regs

NZCFS L5
(US31869 1.1)
step1.comments:
Included in:

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P.24
Disclosure Template(s)

step1.question: Can you evidence where and how you explain your role and obligations of care and skill etc as well as discuss their obligations /responsibilities? e.g. Your process and how you will put their interests first and comply with the Code Their obligation re provision of information and consequences of not doing so.
step1.source:
Code Std 2
Code Std 4

NZCFS L5
(US31869 1.1)
step1.comments:
Included in:

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P.2
Disclosure Template(s)

step1.question: Can you evidence that the Nature and Scope of Advice for the Engagement (including any limitations) discussed, agreed and documented before proceeding with the advice process?
step1.source:
FSLAA S431J
Code Std 4

Disclosure Regs

NZCFS L5
(US31869 1.1)
step1.comments:
Note where this occurs. The purpose of the process/engagement should be established before information can be gathered.

Included in EI Fact Find Needs Analysis Template pp 24, 2

step1.question: Can you evidence that your remuneration for service has been explained and agreed?
step1.comments:
Included in:

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template pp 2,3
Disclosure Template(s)

step1.question: If a client declines to undertake a full suitability or needs analysis, is this decision noted in writing and signed and dated by the client acknowledging the advantages of a suitability analysis and the limitations of not undertaking one?
step1.comments:
Note: This requirements is part of the current Code of Conduct for AFAs.

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P3

step1.question: Do you note any other specific tasks requested by the client?
step1.comments: EI Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P2

step1.question: Do you explain how information you gather is used, the security of this information and who has access? (Privacy Statement and Acknowledgment)
step1.source:
Privacy Act

Code Std 5

NZCFS L5
(US31869 1.1)
step1.comments: EI Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P3

step1.question: Do you get client(s) sign off on the Scope of Engagement and Privacy Act explanations and other acknowledgements e.g. receipt of documents?
step1.comments:
Required to prove the requirements above have been completed.

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P3

step2.question: Do you use a formal Fact Find Needs Analysis Document or Technology Platform that is designed to uncover all client circumstances having a bearing on the advice as per the agreed nature and scope of the engagement?
step2.source:
FMA Capability Requirement

Code Std 3
Code Std 1

Best Practice
step2.comments:
Note: The extent and level to which information is gathered will be determined by the agreed nature and scope of advice for the engagement.

Code Std 1 talks about “listening to clients, considering their views and responding to their concerns and preferences.” This applies to several aspects of the needs analysis process below including the ‘Know your client’, act with integrity and ‘Treat clients fairly’ expectations.

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template

step2.question:
Throughout the process, do you formally establish and seek to understand and validate the clients attitude to and capacity for risk (risk tolerance) in accordance with the agreed Scope of Engagement? Including:
  • General attitude (willingness) to accept risk or self-insure
  • Priorities for cover type and identified needs
  • Self-insurance levels or time frames e.g. use of wait period / excesses
  • Availability and willingness to use own assets or borrow (capacity) including liquidity
  • Willingness to accept risk
  • Willingness to use family support / Government support / Public health services
step2.source:
Code Std 3

FSLAA S431
K and M

NZCFS L5
US31866 1.1
US31869 1.2
step2.comments: EI Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P4

step2.question: Do you discuss with the client and record their personal objectives (reasons) for implementing a risk insurance plan relevant to the agreed nature and scope of the engagement?
step2.source:
Code Std 3

FSLAA S431 K/M

NZCFS L5
US31866 1.2
US31869 1.2
step2.comments: EI Fact Find Needs Analysis Template P4

step2.question:
Do you discuss with client, listen and record sufficient qualitative information about the client’s personal situation relevant to the agreed nature and scope of the engagement that may impact on needs? For example:
  • Personal circumstances including obligations, values/beliefs, aspirations, goals etc) especially around
    • Family
    • Work (income sources)
    • Housing
    • Money/Investments
    • Lifestyle
  • Business Circumstances
  • Any reasonably foreseeable changes to these circumstances
step2.source:
FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 1
Code Std 3

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.3
step2.comments:
Note: The Privacy Act is very important here. You can only gather personal information form the person themselves and such information must be in line with the purpose as per the Scope of Engagement.

AL Fact Find Needs Analysis Template

step2.question:
Do you gather and record sufficient quantitative client information relevant to the agreed nature and scope of the engagement to be able to make sound recommendations? For example:

Personal details such as:
  • dates of birth, address, marital status, and residency status
  • health status, pastimes and habits
  • employment status and nature of the job
  • Children
  • Estate planning provisions including details use of other advisers (e.g. accountants)
Financial circumstances and details such as:
  • Assets (relevant to advice) including ownership
  • Current and potential liabilities
  • Level and nature of income from all sources
  • Existing insurances
  • Initial quantification / calculation of needs
step2.source:
FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 1
Code Std 3

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.2
US31866 1.3
US31866 1.4
US31866 1.5
step2.comments: EI Fact Find Needs Analysis Template

step3.question:
Do you review all client information to identify circumstances that will impact on strategy and product solutions and how these may be incorporated into the advice?

Consideration can include:
  • Current assets
  • Current insurances
  • Health, family history, existing conditions, hazardous pursuits, habits, residency.
  • Sophistication of client (skills, experience and vulnerability)
  • Possibility of loading / exclusions
  • Time frames i.e. short-term needs versus long- term needs and affordability
  • Risk tolerances e.g. for wait period, benefit levels and excesses
  • Reasonably foreseeable changes to circumstances e.g. family status, inheritances, increased debt, change of employment situation, asset acquisition
  • Client’s stated priorities /preferences
  • Taxation implications
  • Alternative strategies if insurance not possible.
step3.source:
FMA capability requirement as per their website

FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 3

FMA Guide on Care Diligence and Skill

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.3
US31867 1.1-1.3
US31866 2.2
step3.comments:
This is further evidence of how an adviser has undertaken care, diligence and skill to determine the most appropriate solution for the client both now and considering reasonable foreseeable changes to circumstances.

It is not just about selecting the best rated product by price or benefits. There can be a lot of filtering of possible structure offerings, attributes and other available solution strategies that need to be considered before product comparators are used.

Note these words from the FMA Website under ‘Monitoring’ … “Write it down. Make sure you've documented how you got to the conclusions you reached for your clients”

AL template ‘Research and Analysis – Personal Insurance
AL template ‘Research and Analysis – Restructuring ACC for the Self-Employed”

step3.question:
Do you analyse and evaluate the availability and use of alternative sources of support as part of the overall strategy and solution. For example:
  • ACC
  • WINZ
  • Ministry of Health
  • Primary Health Organisations
  • Family
  • Self-insurance
step3.source:
FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 3

NZCFS L5
US31867 2.1

step3.question:
Do you research, analyse and evaluate existing insurance covers to determine if still fit for purpose. This may include such things as:
  • Product features and options comparisons (loss or gain)
  • Existence of special concessions in existing cover
  • Impact of new health conditions, occupation, pursuits and habits on any proposed cover (potential loss of benefits /cover)
  • Premium projections and comparisons over the longer term
step3.source:
FMA Guide on Care Diligence and Skill

FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 3

NZCFS L5
US31867 1.3
US31866 2.1
step3.comments:
This aspect singled out as it has a large ‘commentary’ in the Code as well as FMA focus.

AL template ‘Research and Analysis – Personal Insurance

step3.question: Do you consider and model different solution options based on client needs, client needs, circumstances and/or client priorities.
step3.source:
FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 3

NZCFS L5
US31867 1.1-1.2
US31866 1.5

step3.question:
Do you carry out relevant research and analysis to identify products and providers which provide solutions to meet the client’s needs and circumstances. This may have included (but not limited to) such things as:
  • Availability of product structures, options and benefits that match required strategies (including ownership options and premium structures)
  • Premium comparisons over the short and longer term
  • Provider financial standing
  • Possible underwriting outcomes by different providers
  • Provider reputation and adviser experiences
step3.source:
FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 3

NZCFS L5
US31867 2.2

step3.question: Do you identify and evaluate any reasonably foreseeable limitations, risks and disadvantages of the products or solutions recommended.
step3.source:
FSLAA
S431 L, M & I

Code Std 4

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.4

step3.question: Are notes on your rationale leading to the advice (research and analysis outcomes as above) documented and on file?
step3.source:
Best Practice

FMA capability requirement as per their website
step3.comments:
Note: In some situations, in-depth research and analysis may not be required given the client circumstances and nature of the advice (Code commentary)

Also, in simple situations the outcome of research and analysis may be evidenced in the SoA itself.

step3.question: Are you satisfied any product research or analysis not conducted by you can be relied upon and can you demonstrate this?
Do you identify and evaluate areas where the client needs to get specialist advice such as a legal, estate planning or accounting

step4.question: Do you provide a written record or Statement of Advice to your clients?
step4.comments:
Note: Not all Advice needs to be in a formal SoA. In simple situations it could be verbal with appropriate recorded calls or file notes created at the same time as the advice. This might be common when further advice is given to an existing client.

AL: Model SoA template

step4.question:
Are recommendations in the Statements of Advice written/presented in a clear, concise and effective way and suitable to:
  • The level of sophistication of the client?
  • Any identified client vulnerabilities?
  • The level and nature of the advice as agreed in the Scope of Engagement.
step4.source:
FSLAA
S431 J, K, L, & M

Code Std 4

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.4
step4.comments:
Note: This includes logical ordering, highlighting key information, explain any jargon in simple language whether written or verbal and avoidance of lengthy documents.

AL: Model SoA template

step4.question: Do you check all advice documents to ensure there are no misleading (or likely to mislead) statements or omission of relevant information?
step4.source:
Fair Trading Act

FSLAA
S431 J, K, L, & M

Code Std 4

step4.question: Do you restate the Scope of Service and any other terms of the engagement?
Do you summarise key relevant facts and client circumstances on which your advice is based?
Do you summarise the client’s core needs and objectives (in personal and practical terms) and their priorities?

Does the advice clearly outline any considerations in arriving at your advice? For example:
  • Client’s risks tolerance/capacity
  • Priorities
  • Choice of product provider
  • Known limitations to the advice e.g. needs identified but unable to address, insufficient information provided
  • Reasons for cancelling or retaining existing cover
  • Any restrictions to being able to provide best possible solution e.g. health status of client and any alternative risk management strategies
  • Government support available and their impact
  • Tax implications
step4.source:
Code Std 3

FMA Guide on Care Diligence and Skill

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.4
US31867 2.1
US31869 1.3

Best Practice

step4.question: Does your advice clearly define the underpinning strategies recommended to address client’s needs and objectives?

Does the advice clearly state how your product recommendations will meet the needs, circumstances and objectives of the client? This may include:
  • Cover types and benefit structures
  • Sums insured
  • Premium type(s)
  • Optional Options recommended
  • Ownership structures recommended etc
Is the advice presented based on identified needs <u>and not modified</u> to represent the client’s final decision e.g. Accepting only part of the recommendation?
step4.comments: A SoA should represent what you advised and explained before making adjustments/variations and proceeding with any implementation. The SoA can have a place to note the variations and made and accepted by the client OR a supplementary statement of agreed actions sent to the client.

step4.question:
Does the advice clearly state any identified risks, limitations or disadvantages of the recommended strategies or product solutions? For example:
  • Needs identified but not addressed
  • Replacement of policy and possible risks and consequences of non-disclosure
  • Insufficient provision of information
  • Not implementing the recommendations
step4.source:
FSLAA
S431 J, K, L, & M

Code Std 4

FMA Guide on Care Diligence and Skill

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.4

step4.question: Does the recommendation clearly outline the premium costs (or your fees) of implementing the recommended strategies and products?
step4.comments:
Note: For risk advisers this will be captured under the new Disclosure Regulations

AL: Model SoA template

step4.question:
Do you clearly and effectively communicate any conflicts of interest that might influence your advice
e.g. qualification for higher commissions or qualifications for overseas trips and other incentives?
step4.source:
Disclosure Regs

Code Std 2

NZCFS L5
US31869 1.4

step4.question: Is the need for the client to seek other legal or specialist advice identified and noted in your advice? For example: need for Wills, EPAs etc.
Can you evidence you meet all applicable Disclosure Regulations required at this point of the process?

step5.question: Is there an appropriate place recording any client- initiated variations to the advice?

Do you explain the process of implementation of any strategies and insurance solutions including possible time frames and impact of other requirements such as medical examinations, use of other professionals etc?
Do you discuss the reasons for a review of their plans and products? Is such a <u>review</u> and an appropriate time frame and method recommended and agreed by the client?

Does the client sign an Authority to Proceed? For example:
  • Proceed with full recommendations
  • Proceed with noted variations
  • Do not proceed with recommendations
Do you carefully support the client through the application questions to ensure they fully understand the disclosure requirements and complete all necessary documentation?

Do you send a copy of their application(s) and reminding them of their Duty of Disclosure? This letter could include:
  • Matters they may have overlooked
  • Health/Occupation changes since application
step5.comments: EI: Example letters/e-mail wording for paper and electronic applications

step5.question:
Do you monitor and maintain tracking records (file notes) of the application and implementation process to ensure it is keeping within agreed time frames and to keep the client informed? For example:
  • Discussion with underwriters / new business staff
  • Follow up conversations and actions on outstanding requirements
  • Discussion of variation to terms of cover and acceptance or otherwise
step5.comments:
Part of the expected communication conduct requirements set down by the FMA

Most will be recorded in CRMs today

AL example / manual checklist for the end to end process.
AL File Note template

step6.question: Can you evidence how you communicate with clients to determine if circumstances and needs have changed (triggers) and/or communicated with client and arranged a review
Can you evidence you meet all applicable Disclosure Regulations required at this point of the process?

Conducted a check with the client to understand and identify changes in circumstances and /or needs that will necessitate strategy or insurance product changes. Changes may include (but not limited to) such things as:
  • Relationship status
  • Family status and responsibilities
  • Employment
  • Nature and source of income
  • Other financial circumstances including assets and liabilities
  • Insurances in place (acquired or ended/cancelled)
  • Risk tolerances and objectives
  • Health
  • Pastimes and habits
  • Goals and aspirations
  • Beneficiaries
step6.comments:
Circle back to the previous steps for the process and drafting recommendations etc.

AL: Review Interview template

Note:

Other requirements replicate those of the full advice process but usually to a much to a lesser extent unless a full revamp of the strategies and product options is required.
